C<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>1.  Write a set of input-output rules that represents the following word problem.<n>   <n>``` <n>Input: 12 boys and 12 girls <n>Ouput: 10 boys and 20 girls <n>```<n><n>2.  Write a set and sequence the rules to solve the following problem.<n><n>```<n>Input: 4 apples on Saturday <n>Output: 4 apples + 3 apples = 7 apples. <n><n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Answer:<n>1.  A set of input-output rule:<n><n>``` <n>Inputs: x and y <n>Output: x - y <n>```<n><n><n>2.   The sequence of step 1:<n><n>``` 	<n>The set of rule: <n>x + y = 12<n>Output: 12<n><n>The set of rule if x = 4 and y = 4:<n>x + y = xy + x + y<n>x + y = (4 x 4) + (4 x 4 + 4 + 4)<n>72<n>Output: 72<n><n>The set and sequence of rule to solve the problem:<n>The output: 72<n>```<n><n>-

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people standing on a line near a road? Choices:  A: water fountain B: military base C: apartment D: fire house E: bus stop<n><n>### Response:		Choice C<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>A) Choose one choice to complete these sentences<n><n>### Demand:Whose house is the tallest of these two houses?<n><n>D) Choose one choice that is not a part of the sentence<n>

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The crowd wasn't that big.  It can better be described as what? Choices:  A: field B: alone C: small group D: solitude E: solitary<n><n>### Response:		The crowd wasn'ty big. It can better be described by choice "C" because a small group is generally two or more people.<n><n>### Input/Expectation:Write a response that appropriately answers the following multiple choice question by choosing Choice "A", "B", "C", "D", or "E".<n><n>### Answers:1.5<n><n>### Inputs:<n>In a group of 34 students, how many students are in school?<n>Rationales : 34 can be divided into 3 evenly so there are 11 students in the school.<n>### Example Output:<n>### Rationales:<n>Anthony has 2 pairs of jeans. There are 3 pair of jeans altogether.<n>### Input: Tony has 2 pairs of shoes. There are 3 pairs in total.<n>### Example:<n>3 pairs<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Rational:<n>If 8213691232019782=a, then 8213=b and 36912=c<n>### Example: 8213,82136,36912<n><n>### Input\Expectation:<n>Write a response the appropriately completes the multiple choice task below.<n><n><n>### Demand:<n>Choose a response that appropriately responds to the task.<n>### Input:\Expectation:<n><n><n>### Input-\Expectation:\Rationales:<n><n>### Input:\Rationales:In a group of 4127, how many students are there?<n>### Example:4+127<n><n>### Input:-:<n>Input:<n>If 239+81=b, then 2+8-9=c<n>Input:<n>If n!=-99, then 5!=(2*2)(2!)-(8!)-89=d<n>Input:<n>If-3=n-2 and -2=n-3, then n=?<n>Input:<n>a+b=2c, then a=?<n><n>### Input-:<n>-<n>### Input-:\Expectation: <n><n>- 100<n>- 6/7<n>11
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If clothes have developed a smell and can't be washed what should you do with them? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demorastion:<n>Inadequate learning would result in inadequate intelligence due to a lack of education.<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Demostratoin:<n>D is not a correct response due to the following reason:<n><n>Distress is a feeling of anxiety or sadness that can result from any situation where you're feeling stress, for example, an exam. Even though studying can be stressful, the feeling is not directly associated with the inability to learn.<n><n>Effectiveness is the ability to do something well. It can't be a result of an inability to learn. It follows that effectiveness and the ability to learn would happen together, or at the least, after the inability to learn has been resolved.<n><n>Education leads to intelligence.<n><n>Intelligence leads to learning.<n><n>Learning leads to higher academic performance.<n>Essentially, one can deduce that the higher the level of education, the higher chances to perform on an exam are.<n><n>#### 5-4-21-13=<n>Answer: A<n>

Choices:  A: eaten B: glassess C: jar D: pizza E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		_____ Answer: E<n><n>### Rationales:Food can get wet easily due to the presence of water. Water can damage food easily when it gets into the food. Olives are a good option if you do not have a container to store your food.<n><n>### Input:[101, 56, 4, 30, 75, 22, 25, 64, 9]<n><n>### Response:[64, 9, 22,56, 25,4, 101, 30,75]<n><n>### Rationale:The list of numbers needs to be placed in ascending order of the numbers. This should be done in reverse chronological order.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>### Input:@"Liz is 6 feet tall. Her brother is 20% taller than her. How many times taller than her mother is her brother?"<n><n>### Rules: The parenthesis are placed to remind a reader of how to read the question. For example, the first set of parentheses is there to tell a reader that Liz's brother is 20 percent taller than her. The second set of parentheses tells a reader that her brother is X amount of time taller than her mother.<n><n>### Response:"260"<n><n>### Ratios:Her mother is ___% taller than her brother.<n><n>### The % should be in front of the number.<n><n>### % Liz is 6 feet<n><n>### Example to use later: 6 feet = 6 x 4.5 inches<n><n>### Roles<n>* 6 / 4 = 1.5<n>* 1.5 x 4.5 = 6.75 inches<n><n>*Her mother is 2.5 times 4.5 = ___ inches taller than her brother<n><n>*Her mother = 122.5 inches<n><n>*6 x 2.5 = 15 inches<n><n>* her brother is 15 - 122.3 = 99.3 inches taller than her mother<n><n>### Input:"Five is twice as much as two. What is three times 5?"<n><n>### Response"15"<n>

What might he have been feeling? Choices:  A: pressure B: death C: trying harder D: quitting E: winning or losing<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Option: D:Quitting<n><n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question:<n>### Demonstraition: <n>Input: There are 30 boys at a party and 30 girls. 2 boys and 2 girls sit together at every table. At each table, 8 children and 4 adults are seated.  All of the children and adults have to sit. How many tables can there be?<n>Rationales : To make 8 children and 2 adults sit at each table, each child must be with 2 adults.  Therefore, we need to divide 4 by 2 adults (each has 2 children, so we need to divide with one child) to get the number of children needed to fill the table.  The calculation will be 4/2 = <<4/2=2>>2 children per adult.  So, we need 4 children to sit beside 2 adults, which means each table can only hold 4 child and 2 adults.<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>####Input:  A man has 20 apples and leaves the next day for a 10 day voyage.  On the first day, he gives exactly one third of the apples to his daughter.  How many apples does his daughter have remaining after each day?<n><n>#### Option: C<n><n>####Answer: 16, 10, 6, 4, 2,  1<n><n>### Response :<n>Input: A man has 27 eggs.  The next day, his daughter breaks 4 eggs and she eats 5 of the eggs. How many eggs does he have remaining?<n>Output: 27-4-5 =<<27-4-1=18>>18<n>Rationales:<n>- He has 27 eggs to begin with because he breaks 4.<n><n>- He gives 5 eggs to his daughter because he eats 5 eggs. So, he must have 18 eggs to eat.<n><n>- He has 18 eggs to break after giving 5 eggs. He can keep only 2 eggs from 18 after that because he needs one egg to eat everyday.<n><n>### Multiple Choice Question<n><n>### Demostration Input: The sum of two numbers is
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:A man was driving himself to the airport, where did he put his luggage? Choices:  A: closet B: at hotel C: sidewalk D: bus stop E: trunk<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>---<n>### Explanation:<n>- This man is going by himself, so he put his luggages in trunk.<n>- Therefore, the correct answer is "C: trunk"<n>---<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If I am forgiving, what hidden force may be activated in my life? Choices:  A: downtown area B: urban area C: new york city D: shopping mall E: military base<n><n>### Response:		The answer is E<n><n>### ANSWER:<n>Answer: B is correct.<n>A: Downtown area is in a city center, which is usually the central point of a city.<n>B: Urban area is any area that is full of a large number of people, houses, and businesses.<n>C: New York City is a place in the US.<n>D: Shopping mall is a place where you can shop for various things like clothes, shoes, and etc<n>E: military base is a restricted place for military people and is not like a city center place<n><n>### Explanation:<n>B: Urban areas are those places where you can see houses and businesses. You can also find a large number of people in an urban area.<n><n>C: New York is a place name and is not a place like urban areas.<n><n>D: Shopping Malls are places where you can go shopping for various things like clothes and other.<n><n>E: Military bases are restricted places located on the city's outskirts or in towns. A military base is not somewhere like a place where you can find businesses and houses and is different from an urban area.<n>A: Dow is not a place that is full of a big number of people, and there is no business and only a city center. In addition, people don't usually go shopping there.<n>####<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Actions & Observations<n>The students who were taking the test completed the questions easily, showing a high level of understanding, but students who were not familiar with the concept of algebra sometimes gave up during that step. The students, who did not give up and stayed focused on the problem had a higher chance of getting the right answer. The concept of "along with" is a bit like "as well as" which are not used on the GRE test. However, to find one of the right answers, it was necessary to have some knowledge of the general concept of "along" as well as "along with" and the other vocabulary such as "alongside," "next to," and "besides."<n><n>### Recommendations<n>GRE teaching should be more focused on vocabularies, and more practice should be provided for conceptual concepts.<n><n>### Scaffolding<n>To scaffold the vocabulary of "

Choices:  A: get arrested B: problems C: sober D: intoxication E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demand & Supply & Equilibrium<n><n>### Input<n><n>Why does supply and demand change? Choices:<n>  A: price B: market conditions C: supply D: number of people E: production<n><n>### Response<n><n>### D<n><n>### Question:What happens to supply when a company lowers its price?<n><n>### Demands increase, supply decreases.<n><n>### Question2:<n><n>### Input/Instruction:<n><n>Input: When market conditions cause an increase in demand, the price<n>increases. When a company provides more of a commodity to meet<n>increased demand, the supply rises. Supply and demand are said to be<n>in equilibrium when supply and demand are roughly equal. When the<n>supply of an item is not equal to the demand for it, the result is an<n>equilibrium in which the price changes. That is, the price is higher when<n>demand is above supply and lower when supply is greater than demand.<n><n>Directions: Select all pairs of answers from the Choices section that<n>provide the complete answer to the request. Then write the complete<n>request in the space provided.<n><n>#### <n><n>Answer: 1,2<n>#### <n><n><n>### Input&Instructions1<n>If demand decreases, then supply<n>A. increases<n>B. stabilizes<n>C. decreases<n>D. rises<n><n>```<n>1. When market conditions cause a decrease in demand, the price decreases. In response, the supply declines. When supply and demand are roughly in<n>equilibrium, equilibrium is achieved when demand and supply are equivalent. If demand for a product drops, the price drops. The decline in supply causes the<n>product to disappear from store shelves.<n>```<n><n>### Input2<n>If supply increases, then demand<n>A. increases<n> B. stabilizes<n>C and D. are stable<n>In response, the supply goes up. When supply and demand become roughly equivalent, supply and demand come into balance. As a result, the price changes to<n>reflect the fact that the amount of supply offered has changed. When demand for some products increases, so does the amount of product that is available to<n>supply that demand. As a result, prices drop.<n><n><n>### Question3<n>Input: What is

Choices:  A: satisfaction B: good feelings C: complications D: feel good about yourself E: stress<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Answer:A<n><n>### Input:(Continued):One day, a girl asked him for directions from her house to the local library. Add the two boxes with the same number of tapes<n><n>2. Remove first square on both sides (remove from opposite ends)<n><n>3. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is something you do  in a bank? Choices:  A: make noise B: have tea C: make time D: make payments E: take time<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationales:Answers B through E are about what you do in a bank. A is about what you do in general.<n><n>### Input A: What do you get if you cut off the right side of a square?Choices are 2, 1, 4, 5Answer: A<n>This question might be about the numbers around the square on the graph.

Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>B- Militar<n><n>### Correct answer:<n>B- Military<n><n>The woman checked her bag, so she must have been heading to somewhere where she was checking a bag. There is no way someone would check a bag to a destination such as a garbage can or military site, but those places are where a person would check a bag. The only other choice available is an airport, but even then, a person would not check a bag to an airport since it is obvious they would bring it in and out without a ticket. Therefore, E is incorrect. D is incorrect because even with a destination with luggage service, many stores will allow people to carry their own bags. A, C, and B remain correct. Military is not correct because the only checkpoints at military bases are at entrances and exits. However, A and C are still correct because airports are considered military bases and are, therefore, not correct.<n><n>## Conclusion:<n><n>In order to improve this lesson or unit, there are four areas on which to focus. One of these areas is how to introduce new material. A unit for fractions could be a good option, but the unit would come before instruction on a unit on division. Another area is the student-centered part of a lesson where questions are answered. The instruction has problems because it is not providing the opportunity for students to answer, which is important for the students to understand their understanding. This helps in making the problem clear, which will also improve student understanding of the question and the answer. There is not information regarding incorrect answers, which will help the student learn more, and it might not be obvious how an answer may be wrong. <n>

Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		<n>If your answer is E, then what happens to your grapes?<n><n>#### B<n>1. Do you lose the grapes?<n>2. Do you still have the grapes? Is the answer to the above question Yes or No?<n><n>#### E<n>1. If your answer is B, then you don't have the grapes.<n>2. Do you lose the super market grapes?<n>3. Do you still have fruit grapes? Is your answer to the above question, Yes or No?<n>3. If so, then your answer is B.<n>4. If not, then your answer is E.<n>#### E<n>1 Does the super market have the grapes or fruit market?<n>2. Has the super market lost the grapes, Yes or No? If answer is no, that they can't have lost the grapes. Therefore, B.<n>3. If the answer is Yes, the market has the grapes, so answer is E.<n>4. If the fruit market has lost the grapes of A. Then that market is D.<n><n>#### D<n>1. Is there any other market that has fruit grapes?<n>#### A<n>1. Is there anyone in your choice who does not want the grapes? If Yes, then your answer is D. If there is not anyone who doesn't want grapes, then your answer is A.<n><n>### Input<n>Sarah has 8 books for reading. Sarah, Michael, and Jack are going to the library. Sarah hands her 6 books to Michael. Which of the following equations is true if there are no other books in the world? Choice A: 8 + Michael’s books = 14 Choice B: Michael’s books + Sarah’s books = Sarah’s books = 6 Choice C: Sarah’s books + Michael’s books + Jack’s books = 8 Choice D: 8+8=8<n><n>### Rationale<n>In Choice A, Sarah hands Michael 6 books. 6 books is the same as adding 6 books to Sarah's 6 books. 8 + 6 books =14 books<n>In Choice B, Michael gives Sarah and Jack one book each. Michael's 6 books are 6 + 1 book = 7 books. Michael'

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Of all the rooms in a house it was his favorite, the aromas always drew him to the what? Choices:  A: yard B: basement C: kitchen D: living room E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>Of all the rooms in the house, it was his favorite because the aromas always led him to the gardens.<n><n>### Answer: E<n><n>### Demostration: The answer is choice E because it is what the author drew him to. And that means the author liked gardens and the aromas. The answers from choice A to C means he loved yards, basement and kitchen.<n>#### D<n>Answer: E<n><n>## Demostration:<n>You are given a description of a person or thing but must figure out who or what it is. Choose the correct description.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>> It is a pond<n><n>### Demosation:<n>It is a pond.<n><n>## Demostrating:<n><n>### Instructions:<n>A paragraph in the text is followed by four questions, each with four choices corresponding to the text. Choose the best answer and click on button <mark> 2.00 pt A</mark>.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would you expect to find a pizzeria while shopping? Choices:  A: chicago B: street C: little italy D: food court E: capital cities<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n>Input:<n>What are the coordinates of (- 6, - 15)?<n><n>Rationales:<n>- 6, - 3<n>Answer:<n>The coordinates of (- 6,-15) are (6,3).<n>Input:<n>Which of the following equations could be used to get the cost of two bananas and two apples ($2)?<n><n>Rational :<n>y = 2(x + y + 6)<n><n>Input:<n>What is the domain of this function?<n><n>Rational : The domain is 0 < x < 6.<n><n><n>### Input :What is the x coordinate of the point (-19, 45)?<n><n>Rationale: The y coordinate is -19.<n><n>#### 45<n>Answer: -19<n><n>### Input <n><n>Which of the functions below has an x intercept along the x-axis at the value of 8? A. y = -4x + 7 B. y = -14x + 11 C. y = -8x - 3 D. y = -3x + 6<n><n>Rational : C : y = -8x-3<n><n>### Input<n><n>Which of these values is positive, negative, or zero?<n><n>Rational: -4<n><n>Answer: -4<n><n>### Input::<n>1. ___ is greater than 3.5 and less than 4.4.<n>2. 4 ___ are greater than 0.75 and less than 1.5.<n><n>Rational:<n>Both are correct<n>(3.5, 4.4)<n><n>#### 1.<n>Answer:<n>3.6<n>#### 2.<n>Answer:<n>4.15<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>What's the greatest common factor (GCF) of (0,0)?<n><n>Rational: 0<n><n>#### #1<n><n>What's 9 + 14 + 20<n><n>##### #2<n><n>Answer: 8

Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		You can share files with someone via a computer network.<n><n>`Computers talk to each other over electrical circuits. The connection to exchange information is a computer network`<n><n>**Electrical circuits are the networks that contain electrical wires and they are used to transport and deliver power to and from places.<n><n>On the other hand, the computer network or network infrastructure is the connection that you can share files with somebody via the internet.`<n><n>A: freeway<n>B: radio<n>C: wires<n>D: computer network<n>E: electrical circuit<n>Answer: D: computer network<n><n>### Input:`If you have a 7-foot ceiling in your bedroom, how high is the ceiling when you add 11 inches to it`<n><n>### Response:`The ceiling is 8 feet high.<n><n>`8 feet is 1 foot + 7 feet. If you start at 7 feet, you count by 1 foot and then add 7 feet to get 8 feet.`<n><n>B: 8 feet<n>D: ceiling<n>Answer: B: 8 feet<n><n>### Input<n>You can connect to a network by connecting a computer to a what? Choice: A: bridge B: ethernet port C: dslm port D: lan card E: router<n><n>### Response<n>You can connect to the internet by using a router, also known as a hub when networking your home. You can connect to a local area network or LAN when networking different computers together.<n><n>`A router transmits data to an internet service provider which is a company that provides internet connection. It helps you exchange data.<n><n>This is typically what you need to connect to the internet by connecting a computer to the router. That way, your computer can connect to the internet.<n><n>A: bridge<n>B: ethernet port<n>C: dslm port<n>D: lan card<n>E: router<n>Answer: E: router<n><n>- [x] 10065_Lesson02_Instructions<n>- [x] Lesson2Exercise2_Exercise2.1_Instr<n>- [ ] Lesson3Exercise2_Rational1.1<n>- [ ] Lessson3Exercise2Rationals2.1<n>- [x] WriteExciseR

Choices:  A: one material often recycled B: ripped C: saturated with water D: one dimensional E: crumpled<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### I:<n>You might crumple a paper and put it outside. Crumpling makes a surface with one dimension. One-dimensional surfaces would be more likely to get ripped.<n><n>### II:<n>One material often used for creating books is paper. Paper is usually made from wood products.<n><n>### I, II: <n>A paper might be exposed to water outside. Water is a possible danger to printings as it damages paper.<n><n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>What is the length of the green line? How long is the total of all lengths?<n><n>### A: 5<n><n>The blue line is 6 inches long. The red line is 4 inches long.<n><n>If it was 6 + 4 in the total, it would be 10 inches.<n><n>The length of the green line is 3 inches. The total is 8 + 3 = <<8+3=11>>11 inches.<n><n>### Input I:What is the length of each of the lines?<n>Rationales A:8 inchesB:10 inches<n><n>### A<n><n>### B<n><n>### C<n><n>### D<n><n>### E<n><n>### F<n><n>### Which length is shorter?<n>Rationales B: A and BA: NoneB: B is shorter<n><n>### I<n><n>The lines are: (1) 8 inches (2) 4 inches (3) 3 inches<n><n>If it was (8 + 3), that would have been 8 + 3 + 10 + 4 = 25<n><n>(8 + (4 + 3)) would be 8 + 7 = 15 inches<n><n>### II<n><n>(8 + 4) + (6 + 10) + (3 + 5) = 25 + 15 + 3 = 43 <n><n>### III<n><n>If 3 were added, it would have been, (8 + 4 + 3) = 15<n><n>### If you added 5 to the sum, it would have been:<n><n>(8 +4 + 3) or (8 + 4) or (8) or 5<n><n>### I answer : 45<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The president is the leader of what institution? Choices:  A: walmart B: white house C: country D: corporation E: government<n><n>### Response:		Choice:B: white house<n><n>### Answer:Choice:B:white house<n><n>### Explanation:It has to be with Capitalization

Over time, a job may be lost. In another survey done 6 years after graduation, what percentage of graduates was still looking for a job?<n>Rationales : 90% x 3 = <<90*3=270>>270 of the 380 graduates (10% left the jobs they found) who had graduated one year earlier still have jobs.<n><n>(Ratio of jobs lost to jobs retained) = <<270/380=0.7>><n><n>The proportion who did not have job (i.e., were still looking for a jobs) are:<n><n>270 - 90% = <<270-90=280>>280<n><n>(Ratio lost to still looking for a job) = <<280/180>><n><n>Ratio of jobs who lost and still looking for a job = (1/(1-0.7)) = 0.315<n><n>Proportion still looking for job = 90/90+90 * 0.31 = 68.5%<n>#### 90<n>Answer: 90<n><n>### Rationales : 12 * 0.45 = 5.40<n><n>#### Answer : 18000<n><n>### Answer : 3421<n><n><n>### 2016:<n><n>So if we have a sum of all positive integers, which are greater than 1, what will be the number of prime numbers.<n><n>Here are the prime numbers that fall in this category.<n><n>1<n><n>2<n><n>3<n><n>5<n><n>7<n><n>11<n><n>13<n><n>So, you can see those numbers in the second equation which is N (4) = 2,<n><n>N (

Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		<n><n># [E]<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Demonstrate the correct mathematical formula.<n><n>```python<n>In(x) = x^2, x > 1<n>```<n><n>### Instrumentation:<n><n>```py<n>Input: x should be chosen by the user.<n><n>Instrumentation:<n><n>    x<n><n>    In(x) = x<n><n>    Input: x<n>```<n><n>## Solution<n><n># [E:In(x)*x^2]*In(x) = *x^2<n>In(x) x = x2<n>```py<n>Input x<n>```<n>Answer: x2<n>```<n><n>## [D:In(x)*10*y]In(x) =10*y<n><n># In(x)*10 * y=10 * y<n># x * In(x)*1, y = x * y<n><n>y = In(x)/10 * y<n>y = y/10<n><n>```py<n>input <n>```<n><n>## Input: 6<n><n>## Instrumentation:<n># Instrumentation: 6 * In(10)/10 = In(10)<n><n># Instrumentation 6 - <n><n>## Solution<n>```<n>In(6) = In(10)/(6-10) * (6)<n><n>In(10) = In(13) * 12/10<n><n>In(13) = In(17)*8, so In(10) = 8^2 * 12/5<n>```<n><n>## Demo:<n>```<n>In(17) = In(8^2)<n><n>In(8^2) = 8^4 * 7.5/2<n>```<n><n># [A:11]Learning languages is hard, even in a full immersion setting, you are likely to make mistakes, which will cause misinterpretations, and that can be uncomfortable and frustrating, and can cause what?, Choices, A: Better Communication, B: Misunderstandings, C: Language Mistakes, D: Headaches, E: Thinking Too Much<n><n># [A] <n><n>```<n>Input: Choose the Answer to a Mathematical Formula to

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What would you do if you want to be able to earn money? Choices:  A: apply for job B: stand in line C: take care of proposals D: pass course E: play the lottery<n><n>### Response:		A (applying for a job)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:They decided to hash things out over drinks, after enough booze they were able to get close on a few things and what? Choices:  A: owner B: foot C: subordinate D: base E: point<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Input: 1. If it takes longer than 30 seconds to make a decision, the head may be yelling at the wrong person. 2. If the head has a point, it’s probably not the person who should be doing decision-making. 3. If the head has never lost a war, the head is probably not yelling at the right person. 4. If the head loses his or her mind,  the subordinate should  definitely not answer. 5. If the head is yelling at a base, the head must be yelling at a point. 6. If the head yells at a point, the head needs to be yelled at by a base. 7. If the points don't move, the head is probably yelling at a base.   8. If the head doesn't know what a point is, the point is yelling at the head. 9. If the head is the loudest person, the head is most likely yelling at the most annoying subordinate. 10. If the subordinate yells at the point, the point is yelled at by the owner. 11. If the owner yells at, but doesn't control, points, the owner is really yelling at points.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>### Explanation: This is a multiple choice puzzle so to determine the head’s yell, you have to eliminate every wrong answer.<n>If it takes longer than 20 seconds to make a conclusion, or it’s the manager’s yell, the answer is B.<n>If the head has a point but hasn’t won many wars, the answer is A.<n>If the head is yelling about a base, but she never loses her mind, it must be A.<n>If the manager is yelling at her subordinate, she must be yelling at point or owner. If she’s yelling at a point, subordinate must be yelling at base instead of owner (the last question).<n>If the points don’t move and the head doesn’t know what it is, he must be yelling at it.<n>Subordinates always have to yell at point to avoid being yelled at by the head (the manager) himself.<n>If the subordinate is the yelliest of all, he’s probably the one the head

How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:How does getting paid feel? Choices:  A: income tax B: satisfaction C: sorrow D: ocean E: bill collectors to happy<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale: C is not an emotion, so E is not a choice.<n><n>### Input:{3+7}<n><n>### Multiple choice Question:What mathematical operation does this represent? Choices: 	A: addition B: subtraction<n><n>### Answer: B<n><n>### Rationales: Since 3 and 7 do not multiply to produce any other number but 21, the only option is that this operation is subtraction.<n><n>### Multiple Choice Question:A man has 16 blue cars and 20 red cars. He wants to evenly divide them among 35 people. How many people get one blue car and one red car?<n><n>### Rationals: We need to solve for x so answer is 8. For example, x = 4. The man has 8 blue cars and 35 red cars. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where do bees congregate with red flowerS? Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n><n>### Response:		Bees congregate where they can gather nectar for flowers' pollination. Because their color has no effect on their ability to find nectar, the correct answer is rose garden.<n><n>### Reference:<n>https://wbk-mam1-media.v-wslearning.net/m/2258205/media/2_02_answer_a.pdf<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The city's community garden was demolished for yet another what? A bird collects seeds. B. An owl builds a house. C. A snail has 90 legs. <n>The city's community gardengrowth was demolished because it was an eyesore.<n>### Demand<n>Rationales:B.An owl builds a house<n><n>### Demonic:The city has a big garden, and no one cares for it. Therefore choice A is the correct answer.<n><n>### Input The skin was broken while shaving, where was this skin damaged? Choices: 1 A: good health 2 B: finger 3 C: meat 4 D: body 5 E: Own family.<n><n>### Response B: finger<n><n>### Rationale:In the question, the skin was broken while shaver, shave describes an action of removing the hair, thus "the skin was broken" means "the skin suffered an injury." Therefore choice B is the correct answer.

How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would a lizard surprise a person? Choices:  A: new mexico B: forrest C: dessert D: garden E: creek<n><n>### Response:		B) forrest<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question or choose all that apply.<n><n>### Input<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If I had a jar which was likely to spoil if left out, where would I want to put it? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy tickets at a ticket booth for games/ Choices:  A: train station B: cathedral C: metro station D: fairgrounds E: amusement park<n><n>### Response:		Tickets for games are generally purchased at the fairgrounds or a metro station.<n>### Output:A and E<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following short answer questions.<n><n>###### Answer: I would like to go to the movie theatre<n><n>I would like to go to a movie theatre.<n><n>######Answer: I don’t see the movies at the movie theatre<n><n>Because movies are only available at certain locations, I do not visit movie theatres on a regular basis.<n><n>### Review & Rephrase:<n><n>###### Instructions:A.Read the passage through. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What do you get for not moving your car during the required time? Choices:  A: towed B: accidents C: driving D: getting tired E: ticket<n><n>### Response:		<n>You could get towed or ticketed<n><n>#### Ticketed<n>Answer <n><n>#### Towed<n><n>Answer<n><n>#### Accidents<n><n>Answer:<n><n>#### Getting tired<n><n>Answer:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		If 'the game was on sale' is the statement to be analyzed, it is an overstatement. It is a misleading statement with no logical meaning on sale is the opposite of a way to much or overpriced, therefore the statement is overpriced.<n><n>### Input(2):Write a fraction that matches each expression. Choices:  A. __/__ B. __/__  C. __/__ D. __/__ E. __/__<n><n>### Demostration: 1/7= __/__ 7/2= __/__ 2/7= __/2__<n><n>### Response (2): A. 17.3 / 54.6<n>B. -93.1 / 62.2<n><n>### Input (3): <n>#### 2. __/__ 6. __/__ 2. __/2__<n>#### 2. 8/24 2. 16/56 16/57<n><n>### Demowration(2):7/97= __/__ a 97/7= __/ 7__<n><n>### Input 3:<n>#### 2.6/7.23<n>####-__/____<n>#### _/12<n><n>### Response 3:<n>#### -25.4 / 30<n>### Input 4.__/6<n>### Demostation A 4/6  B.-10/2 C.14/22 D.16/32 __ Answer __/__ <n>### Input 5.__/2<n>#### __/2__<n>### Demostated 5/9 9/45<n>### Answer __/9__/2__<n><n><n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demos:<n>A:<n>Demos: A: running - A - running<n>B: have fun - B - have fun<n>C: balls touch - C - have fun<n>D: winning - B - have fun, E - win<n>E: get tired - A - have fun<n>```C#,java,python<n>```<n>```c#<n>int A,B,C,D,E;<n><n>Console.Readln('Enter the number A:\t{0}',A);<n>Console.Readln(A==1? '\t{0}': '\t{0}\n',B); //A==1,B==2<n>Console.Readln('\t{0}\n','{0}\n');  //Enter the number B:\t{0}<n>Console.Readln();<n>Console.Readln(\n'\t{0}\n'); //Enter the number C:\t{0}  --> 1<n>Console.Readln;\t{}  --Enter the number D:\t{0} --> 2<n>```<n>```java<n>int i,j,k;<n>i=sc.nextInt();<n>j=sc.nextInt(A);<n>if(i==1)<n>{<n>j=2;<n>}<n>for(int x=0;x <i;x++) {Console.print("\n{0}\t");}<n>}<n>j=sc.oneArgLetter('A');             //Enter the number A:\th<n><n>k=sc.nextInt('B');<n>for(int y=0;y <k;y++) {Console.print("{0}\n",y+i);}<n>//Enter the number B:\th<n>k=sc.oneArgNumber('C');<n>for(int z=0;z<k;z++) {Console.print('{0}\n',z+i);}<n>```<n>```python<n>i=int(input("Enter the number A:\n"))<n>j=int(input(i==1?"\n":i==2?"\t":i==3?"\t\t":''))<n>for i in range(1,i+i):<n>    print("\n{0}\n".format(j))<n>```

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston.
