Choices:  A: direct traffic B: board vessels C: arm themselves D: help people E: find drugs<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: Only some types of police direct traffic.<n>### Instruction Rationale: Type the correct answer on your paper.<n>### Answer Rationale: E B<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input:"What's the last thing you do before you go to sleep at night?"<n><n>### Response:"Thank God for my life."<n><n>### Input"What time did Mara go to bed?"<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the following incomplete statements with an appropriate response.<n><n>### Response Rationale:<n>#### No response:<n>Input: "Did you like ________?"<n><n>### Answer Rationales: The question requires a yes or no response. So, there is no need to respond "yes" or "no".<n><n>### Answer: No response<n><n>### Input "Do you think the movie "Murder At A Wedding" is realistic and true to life?"<n><n>### Rationales:<n>#### Acceptable Response:<n>Input: "No, it's not true to life."<n>Answer: No<n><n>### Unacceptable Response:"Wrong."<n><n>### AnswerRationale: The question "Do you think the book `Murder At a Wedding' is realistic... " is about the book _Murder at a Wedding_.<n><n>### Unanswered Response:<n>Input: 1 + 1<n><n>### Instructor Response:<n>Answer"1 or 5"<n>#### 1<n>AnswerRationale: This question is in response to "Can you tell me what the first question you'll see in the book quiz is?"<n>#### 5<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Input Rationales:<n>Input:  Is it true that all 7-year-olds have to go to school?<n>AnswerRationale: 7-year-old = Year 2 child<n><n>Input:  What are some things you do when you're not in school?<n>AnswerRational: Not going to school<n><n>Input:  Is your family from India?<n>Answer: Yes<n><n>#### Yes<n>AnswerRationale: Yes = Accepted<n><n>#### No<n>AnswerRational: No = Rejected<n><n>### Answer:"In class, I'll be talking about math."<n><n>### Instuctor Rationales:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:She'd sooner just spray herself with water than the what she didn't like the smell of? Choices:  A: perfume B: air C: fountain D: swamp E: puddle<n><n>### Response:		A<n>

Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where would one find a captive monkey? Choices:  A: rain forest B: tree tops C: toy store D: zoological gardens E: great outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choosing from the multiple-choice options, the following response represents the appropriate answer.<n><n>### 🗄 Reference<n>- [MATH 1313](https://github.com/chipZhan/MATH1313_H1_2020)<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:If someone is outgoing what are they likely to seek? Choices:  A: new experiences B: playfulness C: own house D: good looking E: beautiful<n><n>### Response:		What are they likely to seek<n><n>#### 1. What are they likely to seek A<n><n>#### B)What are they likely to be<n><n>#### D) What are they likely to be likely to seek<n><n>### Output:<n>Output: If someone is outgoing what he are they likely to seek Choose A new experiences.<n><n><n>### Rationales<n>Input: If someone is out going they are more likely to seek out new experiences<n><n><n>#### Answer:Output: If someone is ou tgoing they are more likely to seak out new  experiences.<n><n>### <n><n><n><n>### Input 1:<n>I think your name is correct.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>I meant to say "your name is [correct]" instead of "your name is correct."<n><n>### Corrected Input:<n>I think your your name is correct. <n><n>### Correct Answer:<n>I think that your name is [correct]<n><n>### 2015/12/18 D:5<n><n><n><n>[Input](./example.1)<n><n>### Output 1:<n>Input: I think your my name is correct.<n>Output: I think your name is correct<n><n><n>### 1.1.<n><n>[Input](ExampleD.1.1)<n><n><n>Output: I'm not sure but is it possible your your name?<n><n><n>```python<n>name = input("Enter your name.")<n>my = name<n>if my == name:<n>    print("Your name isn't '{}'.".format(name))<n>else:<n>    print(name)<n>```<n><n>### 4.<n>[Input]<n><n>```python<n>>>> a, b, c = input("Enter 3 integers: ")<n>>>> a<n>14<n>>>> b<n>35<n>>>> c<n>20<n>```<n><n>## 7.4.<n>[Input](./input.txt)<n><n>```python<n># A<n>import sys<n><n>sys.output = open('output.txt', 'w')<n><n>for i in range(sys.stdin.readline()):<n>    print(sys.stdout.write('\t{}'.format(i))<n>```<n><n>## D:2<n>[Input](./19386947&193
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What sport is the audience the loudest at? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where can you purchase food and eat it at tables? Choices:  A: house B: fast food restaurant C: library D: conference E: paper<n><n>### Response:		Choice: A: house<n><n>Input: Where can you purchase food and where can you eat it at tables?<n>Rationales A: house<n>B: fast food restaurant<n>C: library<n>D: conference<n>E: paper<n>If you only answer D then you did not specify where you can purchase food or eat it at tables<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input,Demonstration, and Instruction:<n>### Instruction,Demonstration: Choose the correct verb form to complete this statement.<n><n>Anita found ⏩ at a garage ⏩. The cost for two hours ⏩ was only $7.

She ordered 5 packs of ski gloves for the trip. Pack 2 has 6 pairs of gloves, Pack 3 has 3 fewer pairs than pack 2, Pack 4 has 9 pairs more than pack 2, and Pack 5 has 9 fewer pairs than pack 4. How many total pairs of gloves?<n>Rationales Pack 2 has 18 pairs of gloves. The class has at least 18 pairs of skingo. Pack 3 has 15 pairs of skingos. So the class has at least 33 pairs. The only way we can get 33 or more pairs without going over is by getting another pack with more than pack 4. Pack 4 has 10 more pairs of skingos than pack 2 which is 15 - 6 = 9 pairs more than 2. Pack 5 has 28-9=19 pairs less than Pack 4. Pack 5 has at least 19 pairs that Pack 4 does not have. So the class has 9 pairs or more from each pack: 10 + 9 + 9 = 28 pairs. However, Packs 2 and 4 each have 12 pairs each. So Packs 2 and Pack 4 actually have 12, 12 pairs of skingos so the class has at least (12 + 12) = 24 pairs of gloves.<n>```<n>#9: 27 pairs<n>```<n>### InputB<n>:The class has 72.5 students. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where can someone purchase a contraceptive device without a prescription? Choices:  A: pharmacy B: person C: drugstore D: bedroom E: mcdonalds<n><n>### Response:		<n>What are contraceptive devices?<n><n>**Contraceptive devices are devices used to prevent pregnancy. A man who plans to get married or take part in a long term relationship may use a diaphragm (a small cap used to cover the opening to the uterus) or condoms. A woman may also use a diaphragms, a cervical cap, the ring, or a sponge in addition to using a condom. Contraceptive devices can be used by a woman to avoid or postpone pregnancy.**<n>These are the only choices.<n><n>**A:** Pharmacy<n> **B:** Person<n> **C:** Drugstore<n> **D:** Bedroom<n> **E:** McDonalds<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: McDonalds<n><n>### Input :The school nurse took samples of the urine of 10 girls and 15 boys. The girls had a median urine volume of 12 ounces, and the boys had a median urine of 17 ounces. For each sample, the urine volume was added and the sum divided by 25. What is the mean urine volume of the 20 students in your sample?<n><n>### Response :<n>The sample was of 20 students and the mean urine volume is 12 + 17/20 = <<12+17/20=7.9>>7.9<n>### Input :12 ounces of liquid were measured at a bar. The ounces were added one after another, without regard to the previous amount, and the sum was divided by 15. How many ounces did each person take?<n><n>### Rationales<n>The people that are mentioned in the question are 1 person and 15 persons<n>The mean should be 8.3 and the standard deviation 5.1.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. Samuel has 5 birds. Answer:<n><n>####<n>Reason:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1) 6 + (-4) +(-3) = 6 -4 -3 = 3<n>2) -3 -1 = -4<n>3) -4 -2 = -6<n>4) -6 -1 = -7<n>5) -3 is not a whole number<n><n>### The answer is D.<n><n>### Choices:<n>1) 4 + (-4 ) = 2 <n><n>### (The minus 4 cancels out with the 4)<n>2) 2 - 4 = -2<n><n>### 3) -4 - 2 = -6<n><n>### 4) -6 - 1 = -7<n><n>### So we have -7 as our answer<n><n>### It can be demonstrated with the numbers to cancel out <n><n>### so we do not get any fractions or a negative number<n><n>### 1) First we take 5 add another -4 so we get 5 - 4  = 1<n><n>### 2) Then multiply with a fraction -0.5 so we get 1 - 0.5 = 0.5<n><n>### <n><n>### 0.5 - 4 = -3.5 <n><n>####<n>Answer A.<n><n>### -7<n>Answer:<n><n>

Where was most of the the broken glass found? Choices:  A: bridge B: in spain C: beach D: field E: street<n><n>### Response:		C = beach. Input: the window of the Honda. This means it was outside.<n><n>### Input and response:<n>Input: The window of the Honda, the Honda parked in the Honda parking lot was hit.<n>Response: A is correct. An incorrect response would be C.<n><n>### Response and Input:<n>Response: D was the correct answer Input: Where was the most of the glass found? Choices A: in spain B: bridge C: beach D: street E: field<n>### Response and input:The word most confused people<n><n>### Instrucction:<n>Which of the following sentence pairs contain information that is inconsistent? Choose all pairs of a sentence that need to be corrected.<n><n>### Inconsistency: A = beach.<n>Instruction: If the car was hit, was the damage done on the inside or outside of the car? This statement is inconsistent. The inside of the car could be hit by anything outside of the car. It could not have been hit at the same time the damage was done to the inside of the car.<n><n>### Another choice of answer:<n>Answer: B = C<n>The sentence doesn't have enough information to make the answer.<n>Answer: E =A<n>The sentence doesn'the have enough information to make an answer.<n><n>### Sentence 1 has incorrect word choice because it is missing the word "damage".<n><n>### Correction to sentence 1:<n><n>#### Sentence 1<n>Input:<n>If the car was hit, where was the damage done? Answer: The damage was done inside the car.<n><n>#### Correction to sentence #1:<n>If the car hit was, where was the damage inside been done?<n><n>### Corrected sentence 2:<n>Sentence2: A was inside the car and B was hit on the outside of the car.<n>Sentence 3:<n>Sentence 2 is wrong because it isn't clear where the damage was done outside the car.<n><n>Sentence #3: If the car was out of the driver's control, could the damage be done inside the car and outside the car? The sentence is not clear.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What creatures performing pollination are loved my millions? Choices:  A: birds B: action C: butterflies D: happiness E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		D birds<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: Input: 20% of the students live on campus. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. I could store the dirt in my computer or in the corner, but I could really live with neither of those options. I like to have clean fingernails, but if the dirt on the bottom of my fingernails isn’t cleaned out, it will end up being in my closet or the garden!<n><n>### Instructions:  Enter a response that you have written and that appropriately<n>completes the request.<n>

Choices:  A: cross street B: milk cow C: lose weight D: step forward E: need food<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>| Response Name: | Response | Response | Response |<n>:---|:---:|:---:|<n>| Response: | A | Cross street | B |<n>| Response: | B | Milk cow | C |<n>| Response: || D | Step forward | E |<n>| Rationales: | A is out of choices | Milking a cow involves moving | Crossing a street does not involve moving around | Crossing a street is similar to walking | Crossing a street involves moving around more than walking | Crossing a cow does not involve moving | Walking is similar to stepping forward | Crossing a street can involve crossing a person | Crossing the cow does not involve crossing a person | Milking a cow does involve crossing a person | Stepping forward can involve crossing a person ||<n><n>#### 7<n>Answer: A<n><n>**Rationales:**Crossing a cow does not require one to cross a person, but one must cross a street. Walking involves moving with the foot, whereas stepping does not.<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: B<n><n>**Rational:**Stepping involves moving around in a location, whereas crossing a cow does not require stepping around since one is already on the cow. Milking involves approaching the cow and walking around to milk it.<n><n>#### 4<n>Answer: C<n><n>**Rationals:**Milking a cow is similar to walking down the street, as one must move to a location to do the task of milking. Milking a cow is similar in that one must walk to milk a cow, and this task results in less weight loss than walking down the street.<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: D<n><n>**Rational(s):**Step forward is similar to crossing a street, but both would likely require one to step around pedestrians. Stepping forward and crossing a street are both tasks of moving forward. Stepping forward and walking are both tasks of moving around.<n><n>#### 9<n>Answer: E<n><n>**Rational (s):**Crossing a person is similar to stepping over a person. Crossing a person is like crossing a street, but one would likely need to get around pedestrians in crossing a person. Walking involves moving out of the way to do the task. These tasks are all tasks

The user must give the option and reason that it may be considered.<n>Choice **A - Station**<n>This is a reasonable choice for the user to go to. This may be because stations are located very near to people's home and they can also be at many places too. <n>Choice **B - Every house**<n>This is a reasoned option as a good number of people has installed a radio in their houses. This could be because radios can be listened to even in the house and do not require people to go out to find one.<n>Choice **C - Shop**<n>This is not preferred because there are not many places that sell radios. It will require the user to go to the shops to get one. This is not an apt choice since the users are looking for an option which doesn't need to go to a shop.<n>Choice **D - Bedroom**<n>This is not a good choice because buying a radio is not done in the bedroom as people don't go to bed with radios and have a tendency to keep them near the TV.<n>Choice **E - Space Shuttle**<n>This is definitely not a good choice as it is not in our world and this cannot be bought there too.<n>Choice **B**<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Learning usually leads to greater what? Choices:  A: get to know B: gain knowledge C: intelligence D: education E: gaining knowledge<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Output:<n>The get to know choice is answered correctly.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The statement is correct. Learning usually leads to greater get to know.<n>#### Gain<n>Answer: A<n><n>* The get to know choice is the correct choice for the learner's experience.<n>#### B: Gain knowledge<n>Answer: B<n><n>* The gain knowledge choice is the incorrect choice for the learner experience.<n>#### C: Intelligence<n>Answer: C<n><n>* The intelligence choice is the incorrect choice of learner's experience, but is the correct answer for the lesson.<n>#### D: Education<n>Answer: D<n><n>* The education choice is the incorrect choice.<n><n>### Input:"Aaron has 5 pairs of shoes and 10 gloves." Which statement describes Aaron? Choices:  (A) Aaron is female. (B) Aaron is the tallest person (C) Aaron has 6 shirts and 2 sweaters. (D) Aaron has as much stuff as someone or something. (E) Aaron likes math and science.<n><n>### Response:"I can determine that Aaron is male because the statement “Aaron has 5 paes of shoes and 5 gloves” does not make any sense"<n><n>### Output:"The answer is B because A is gender related"<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>### Correct answer:Aaron has 10 gloves.<n><n>### Corresponding lesson:<n>Lesson: Addition<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The statement is not true since it's contradictory to the question; Aaron does not have either.<n><n>### Choices (1-4):<n>Correct Answer (1 of 3): Aaron has 10 Gloves<n><n>### Choice 5:<n>The given answers are: C, D, E.<n><n>### Example Output:<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Choose the next correct statement.<n>A. 2 less 1<n><n>A. 2 - 1<n><n>A-21<n><n>A-0<n><n>Answer: 2 - 1=1<n><n>### Chooses the next correct statement. A.<n><n>#### Write a number sentence
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. The choices are A,B,C, and D. So far, the corn field is excluded because E is at Utah which is not in the choices and the corn field is not the view.<n>To narrow it down, A doesn't exclude it as it is given as a place to find. B, C, D are already ruled out because they are not within the choices. Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		The answer is D, the Triple Crown.<n><n>### Rationale: It took me just under half an hour to solve this, so I can't be certain that my methods are optimal.<n><n>### 1. Start by eliminating choices that are clearly wrong. This is just a process of elimination I guess.<n><n>### a. A: race track I know is wrong, but I think it should be disqualified immediately. I think the race track is where they use horses to race, but the Derby is not about the race track or the actual racing, even though it occurs in that place. Eliminate B: Kentucky Derby I'm also going to think the Kentucky Derby isn't actually a "race" or something that can be associated with horse racing so it may not be an option. This is my initial guess after looking through the answer choices and rereading the question to see what I can understand of its context. There were probably other choices that I eliminated too hastily, but A and B are certainly wrong right off the bat.<n><n>### b. C: American Southwest. I'm not really sure. I don't want to say, "well, the horses from the American southwest come through here, and go to the Derby and then come back to the southwest" because I'm not sure which horse from the southwest is competing in the Derby at this point. If one southwest horse can make it, can all of them make it? But maybe, and then they can go back when the Derby is over? Eliminate! Next!<n><n>### c. D: Triple Crown. This makes sense. I just don't put "derby" in my mind when thinking of it in this way. Eliminate E: Horse Derby. This one is probably wrong, but I think I'd like to keep it around for a bit longer in case it's helpful at a later stage. At least, that's the answer I think is most likely.<n><n>### d. 1. Pick some new choices that will improve your odds of getting to the correct one.<n><n>### c'. D: Triple Crown I'll say it's a Triple Crown because: Triple Crown is a horse, Triple Crown race is three specific horse events, and a Triple Crown is a thing that happens and consists of three

When writing or talking about an animal’s name and adding the letter S or ES to the end of the name. Choices:  None of the above Yes No<n><n>### Response 2:When talking people should use an apostrophe<n><n>### Demostiation 2:<n>People should use an apostropeth when talking about animal's name and adding the letters S or ES to the name.  <n>  <n>#### 1<n>answer:yes<n><n>### Input3: When would people use a semicolon? The following examples show how to properly set up a semicolon. 1 Choices:   Yes No<n><n>##demostration3:<n>People should always use semicolon.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: no<n><n>### Input four: In how many minutes will it take a person to drive 3/8 of the distance from New Orleans, Louisiana to Mobile, Alabama? Choices: 2:86400 4:49200 12:316800 112:82700 Hint: Use this ratio to set up the problem. 1/2 = 12:82 = 56 minutes; 1/3 = 12:145 = 175 minutes;   and 1/4 = 12:720 = 300 minutes.<n><n>##demostratino 4:<n><n>Since one quarter of the distance between New Orleans and Mobile is 3/8, it can be set up like so:<n><n>New Orleans to Mobile = 3/8 * 3000 miles<n><n>3/8 * 700 miles<n><n>4/8 = 2/4 * 700 <n><n>3/4<n><n>56 miles<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer:2<n><n>### Input five: John has 3 times as many silver dollars as Morgan. Morgan has 2 times as many silver dollars and pennies as John. How many pennies
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What are people playing when they want to take the lead with small papers? Choices:  A: very heavy B: video game C: news article D: card game E: lead pencil<n><n>### Response:		 D<n><n>### Rationale:  lead PENCIL <n><n>### Input<n>What is the total number of pints in 7.3 gallons?<n><n>Answer: 7.3 gallon is 7.3 gallion. gallions is gallon, so there is 7.3 * 8 = 58.4 pint.

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Choices:  A: fun B: talent C: learn about D: intelligence E: recognize<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. fun<n><n>### Input She has three sons, but how many daughters does she have?<n>### Answer:<n>3 daughters<n><n>### Input Pete walked 5  blocks from his house to garage in Houston. then he rode the bus 60  blocks to the post office. He came home the same way as he started from. How many blocks did he travel in all?<n>### Answer 100<n><n>### Instructions How many apples are there in an apple basket if there are 425  apples in all?<n>## Instructions<n>### Answer 99<n><n>### Instructor<n>Write a response that appropriately complete the request and  answer the question, How many apples are in all?"<n><n>## Instructor<n>### Rationales <n>If a basket has 99 apples, there must be 1 apple missing from the total.<n>In a total of 425 apples, this means it is a basket with 425 — 1 = <<425-1=424>>424 apples in a basket —  1 apple will  be missing.<n>#### 425 - 1<n>Answer: 424<n>[Solution]<n><n>### Instuctort: <n>Write a response that correctly answers the following multiple choice question<n>### Instruectot: <n>How many hours did the two baseball teams play on Saturday?<n>## Answer:<n>### Instructort: <n>Write an answer that correctly completes the instruction, "Answer the following multiple choice questions. Input : If 32 students attended an anime convention, which option correctly describes the situation?<n><n>Choices: 1:  They all wore a green uniform. 2:  They held a costume contest. 3:  They made a green poster. 4:  They wore green accessories<n><n>### Answer: 1<n>### Explain: <n>We will only need to find the students in the green uniform as there are many students that wear anime costumes. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Dave put his beer where he could get to it, but it would be off the floor.  Where did he put it? Choices:  A: refrigerator B: closet C: can D: shelf E: soccer game<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices: A: refrigerate B: closet C,D,E: none of the aforementioned options<n>A: Actions: The key to answering this one is to understand Dave's goals. He put his beer where it would be off the ground "but could get to it."  The refrigerator is the obvious choice. He obviously didn't want to get all the way up on the counter, and since the beer would be off the ground, he could still get it without standing.<n><n>### Input A:The two biggest reasons people prefer working remotely are avoiding the daily rush of traffic and avoiding the commute. I think this is the biggest advantage. Roads are such an antiquated form of travel, a flying car would make transportation seem revolutionary.<n><n>### I found this to be an interesting prompt, as I see the commute as necessary for transportation. I would still like to drive a flying car if one were to be invented. As with most modern technologies that seem revolutionary, flying cars will be expensive. This seems to be the one big deterrent for flying cars. That said, it may be worth it for people to pay a premium to avoid the daily rush of cars.<n><n>### D:What could likely result if people were able to avoid traffic and their commute, and what could likely result if people chose another form of transportation instead? How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. There are 90 legs all together. How many legs were bicycling legs?<n>Rationales : There are 20 women who are not wives or mothers, so 15 x 20 = <<15*20=300>>300 bicycling legs.<n>There are 55 - 20 - 15 - 10 = <<55-20-15-10=24>>24 total legs.<n>So, 300 - 24 = <<300-24=276>>276 legs are bicycling

Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of a village? Choices:  A: rural area B: africa C: ohio D: big city E: tribe<n><n>### Response:		A [1]<n><n>### Input:{1, 2, 3, {1, 2,..., n}, π} <n><n>### What is the fourth element of {1, 2? π}<n><n>### Response:{2} [2]<n><n>### Response:=<n><n>### Response:-<n><n>### Instructions<n>Fill in the blank by choosing the right number:<n><n>### 435 * 100 =?<n><n>### 66<n><n>### Why is 24 * 24 =?<n><n>## Instructions<n><n>### 81<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:It had a beach with shallow water, while not the ocean this was a hot spot all the locals enjoyed on the what? Choices:  A: swimming pool B: pond C: lake D: bathe in E: childrens pool<n><n>### Response:		Swimming pool<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Sometimes, locals enjoyed swimming in the pond. However, this was a hot spot on the sandy area of the lake.<n><n>### A-B-C-D-E<n><n>### D<n><n>### Rate:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Choice:<n><n>### Score:<n><n>### Correct answer:<n><n>### 1:<n><n>### A:<n><n>Input: Mary and John are on a hike together, and they are planning to meet at noon to get lunch. When Mary first gets up in the morning she is 15 minutes closer to noon than John. Mary walks 1500 steps per hour and John walks 3000 steps per hour. At what time will they meet and what distance will they have walked?<n>Rationales:: Mary's per-mile speed was 1500 divided by 15 =<<1500/15=100>>100 miles-per-day.<n>Mary's distance traveled in the morning was 150 minutes + her distance that she traveled was <<150+distance>>distance times 100=distance.<n>John's distance traveven in the morning was 300 minutes + his distance that he travelled was <<300+distance>>distance * 300=distance. John traveled 15 minutes and Mary traveled 5 minutes.<n>Mary traveled 5/100 miles of distance and John traveled 51/100.<n>Their total distance is 5/10 + 51/1 + 100 = 50/101 of a mile<n><n>#### 50/16<n>Answer: 522/63 feet<n><n>### Question:If the number of pizzas ordered, the number of pizzies that were paid for are subtracted from 26, what is the difference?<n>Rationales :26 minus 2<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### QuestionWhat number is it when you add the even numbers to get 24?<n>Rationales:'Even' numbers are 2,4

What did he have left?<n>Rationales::<n>1.The first step is to subtract $7.43 - $0.30 = <<7.43-0.30=7.13>>7.13 from 7.13 = 0.43$. When the man has 0.43 cents he will buy bread.<n>2.<n>2.In the second step, we are to determine the final amount that the man is left with after he buys loaf of bread.<n>a.The rest that the man left with is 7.13-0.43= <<7.13-<n>0.43=7.70>>7.70 dollars and 77 cents.<n>b.He has to divide the 7.70 dollars by 4 since there are 4 quarters in a dollar.<n>3.4+1=<<4+1=5>>5 dollars, 48 cents.<n>4.So, the man left with 5 x 0.25 = <<5*0.25=1.25>>1.25 cents.<n>5.The man ended with 5+0.25=<<5+0.2<n>5=5.25>>5.25.<n>#### 5.25<n>Answer: 5.25 dollars and 50 cents<n><n>### Input<n><n>Raul lost 45 pounds and spent 2 hours cooking to lose it. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What would someone wear to protect themselves from a cannon? Choices:  A: ungulate B: bomber C: body armor D: tank E: hat<n><n>### Response:		A, E<n><n>### Rationale:The answer is on the left, but its explanation appears on the right.<n><n>### Input 2:Two bicycle riders were going from point A to point B. The first rider rode farther than the second rider, and the second rider rode over 2 miles. The first rider had more than double the mileage of the second rider. How many miles did the first rider ride?<n><n>### Input3:In a classroom, there will be 8 girls, 9 ghosts, and 24 pumpkins. Six ghosts are in front of 5 ghosts. The two ghosts that are in front of 17 pumpkins stand behind 14 pumpkins. How many pumpkins are there in a class of 27 pumpkins?<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:My house is very dry, with little water in the air. What tool should I use to fix this? How many students were enrolled in city schools last year?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>There were 475 students the year before and 634 students the year before. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:What would be considered a success when attempting procreation? Choices:  A: celebrate B: have party C: hear crowd go mad D: create success E: reproduce<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input-Rationales: B:  I think when someone tries to breed or give birth.<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>- What is the next in the pattern?<n>A) 3, 5, 7, 9, 13, ___,_.,_<n>B) 5, 7_, 9_,___<n>C)  3, 5, _ _, _ <n>D) 5, 13,29, 45<n>```<n>```<n>Next: 5, 7 _, 9___<n>```<n>### Response<n>```<n>G:  Next is 9___ (I don't know how to spell it)<n><n>M: What is the number for 5?<n>Z: How about 3?<n>G: No, it's for 7 and it's a skip.<n>M: No<n>Z: Yup.. 3<n>G: 5, 5, 5 and 1, 1, 1 for the skip (there is a gap)<n><n>M: That's fine, how about 9?<n>...<n><n>M: What's 5?<n><n>G: That's it<n>M: What' about 9?<n>```<n><n>```<n>Next is 9___<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Rationales: Mara has 150 - 40 = <<150-40=110>>110 cards.<n>Janet has 110/2 = <<110/2=55>>55 cards since Mara has twice as many as Janet.<n>Brenda has 55 - 9 = <<55-9=46>>46 cards since Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda.<n>Therefore, they all have 110 + 55 + 46 = <<110+55+46=211>>211 cards.<n>#### 211<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Rationales: The number of blocks traveled on the way to the post office was 5 + 20 = <<5+20=25>>25.<n>Pete traveled 25 × 2 = <<25*2=50>>50 blocks in all.<n>#### 50<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Rationales: There are 10 x 3 = <<10*3=30>>30 green chairs.<n>The total number of blue and green chairs is 10 + 30 = <<10+30=40>>40.<n>So, there are 40 - 13 = <<40-13=27>>27 white chairs.<n>Therefore, there are 40 +27 = <<40+27=67>>67 chairs in a classroom.<n>#### 67<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Rationales: 4.5 gallons = 4.5 * 8 pints = <<4.5*8=36>>36 pints<n>36/18 = <<36/18=2>>2 pints<n>Genevieve drank 2*3=<<2*3=6>>6 pints of coffee.<n>#### 6<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Rationales: If Beatrix has 30 books, Alannah has 30 books + 20 books = <<30+20=50>>50 books.<n>Queen has 1/5 * 50 books = <<1/5*50=10>>10 more books than Alannah.<n>The total number of books Queen has is 50 books + 10 books = <<50+10=60>>60 books.<n>All three have 60 books + 50 books + 30 books = <<60+50+30=140>>140 books together<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Rationales: A bird eats 7 x 4 = <<7*4=28>>28 berries in 4 days.<n>So, 5 birds can eat 28 x 5 = <<28*5=140>>140 berries in 4 days.<n>#### 140<n>Answer: 140<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to purchase listening vinyl? Choices:  A: safeway B: record albums C: record store D: car E: wallpaper<n><n>### Response:		<n>[12/14]<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Where do most people purchase their listening vinyl?<n>C: Record stores<n>What is the correct answer according to the task instruction?<n>A: Record Albums<n><n>### Additional Explanation:<n>Record albums (C) is not a choice. So the closest choice is (A) safeway, which is (D) car. <n><n>### Answer choices:<n>A: Record Albums  B: Record Stores  C: Record Albums  D: Car  E: Wallpaper    <n><n>### Answer:<n>(D) Car<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>### Input  : <n>Where was the Great Wall of China built?<n><n>### Possible Choices: <n>I do not know A: north China B: East China C: Central to south China<n><n>Option (C) Central to south China is the wrong choice.<n><n>### Option (B):<n>The Great Wall of China was built in East China.<n><n>### Answering Technique: Substitution<n><n>### Rationale:<n>There are three chinas.<n><n>East China: One point<n><n>South China: Two points<n><n>Central to South China: Three points<n><n>### Answer Choices: <n>A: Nothing B: East China C Central to south China D: Nothing E: North China

Choices:  A: more rice B: own house C: warm coat D: light up E: read book<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>If you own a rice farm, your rice is not an option. If you own a house, that is your home. If you have a warm coat, you have clothing. However, if you light up, you smoke tobacco.<n><n>### Input<n>How many days in a lunar month?<n><n>### Rationales<n>The phases of the moon are either full, first quarter, new moon, or third quarter. The number of days between full and new or full and third quarter is the same. And there are 12 full moons in any complete year cycle.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>### Demos<n>How many days in November?<n><n>### Answer<n>30<n><n>## More Questions<n><n>### Question: There are a lot of reasons why someone goes to the doctor and here are a few of them. This is a list of symptoms that the 99.9th percentile, which is pretty unusual, have. And here are some symptoms that the 11% have and the 2% have.<n><n>### Ratiuanses<n>3: Dizzy all the time<n>1: Prayer<n>2: Anxiety<n>4: Aches<n>9: Nausea<n>7: Itching<n>5: Fatigue<n>7: Tingling all over<n>9: Fatigue<n>9: Fatigu<n>6: Fatigue<n>3: Nausea<n><n>### Answer: 6: Fatigue, 3: Dizzy, 5: Fatigu, 5: Foggy, 4: Anxiety, 9: Nause, 7: Tingling<n><n>### Questions: A person needs food to give them energy so they can do what?
